As a matter of fact, the older and wiser crowd at Cary's study group were tossing the term around about a Kamakura blade.  I wanted to inquire, but the discussion moved on, and I didn't get a chance.  I made a note of the term to look it up, and found Hawley's definition, which applied to a sword I have at home.

I think the definition you have provided is more likely what Cary and the gang were talking about, though obviously odd in the case of such an old sword.  Thanks for the information.  

  
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, June 23, 2003 8:23 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha


  David,
  I don't think there are different forms... it's a short section of "unsharpened" edge just above the hamachi.  It's not unusual with gendaito, but is rather rare in older blades.  It is ground away as the blade is polished over time.

  Very old and very good saiha swords that are otherwise intact can sometimes get kanteisho.  

  Hopefully someone more knowledgeable about swords can comment.

  Jim


    Can anyone think of any publications featuring illustrations of different
    forms of ubuha?

    Do retempered swords ever receive papers?
